threads.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

last_replies.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

I have a sit/stand desk and want to build a contraption out of PVC that will hold both my computer and UPS to the underside of my desk-top; the desktop is the Ikea countertop SÄLJAN. The desktop overhangs by about 19" from the support of the desk. The weight of both items together is just shy of 60lbs. The dimensional requirements are: 12.164" W, 17.71" H, 9" D. I figured the best results for weight distribution for the desk-top would be to build a cube using 90° elbows; that way I can use about 8 pipe hanger straps screwed into the desk-top, with wood glue on the screws. 1/2" PVC which will be cemented together.

Has anyone done anything similar? I'm slightly worried the weight might start to bend/sag the desk-top, which will end up damaging it or ripping it apart. Or the screws (even glued) being ripped out over time due to the sheer weight of my PC+UPS. Or the PVC breaking (which is my least concern, I doubt it'll happen, but...) For added support, there's a small gap between the desk and the top, because of large rubber spacers. I could potentially use this space and thread paracord through it; wrap it around the desk leg T and the bottom-right pipe of the cube.

"PC Holders" on amazon that support the weight of what I'm trying to do are expensive--double what the PVC will cost me. Just looking for a simple solution to a minor problem, I don't want to spend a lot of money because I can just keep the stuff how it is, it's just annoying because of cable-routing and management.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504225
60:40 green to brown roughly (just chuck torn up cardboard, paper and leaves in for brown)

3 year cycle:
>Have 3 bays so each bay has 1 year of being filled and 2.5 years to rot down
>When bay one hits 1 year old, start filling bay 2 and don't touch 1 for 2 years
>Turn bay 1 over in the 3rd Autumn to use the following spring (final 0.5 years).
>empty bay 1 onto beds, start refilling it with next year of waste
>you've now completed your 3 year cycle

After 3 years this produces about 800L of compost per year for the house in >>2504107

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 12-20-2021]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini,
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Flashforge creator pro 2
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

You could set up an ardupilot quadcopter with a sony camera, then use opendronemap to make a georeferenced areal map.
After that you would need to produce eg jpeg images of each part of the areal map and use some python package to detect blobs of white of a certain size.
You would need to fly a set height above the terrain (otherwise the blob size would change). This is possible but you would need either a good raster of the terrain or a rangefinder on a gimbal.
It is 100 percent possible to do, just a lot of work, especially if you want an efficient workflow that other people can use.

>>2501775

don't call it super glue. you can call it CA, and you have to specify whether it's thick or thin formulation.

abs doesn't creep as much as petg. I didn't believe in using 3d printed parts permanently, but after seeing people print their gun parts, I'm beginning to change my mind. I'll print most parts in ABS for dimensional stability (don't have to constantly re-tighten screws).

when I had my MDF / 3d printed CNC hot wire, re-aligning the machine (due to humidity changes etc.) took the majority of the time. ABS + metal seems like the way to go, unless you need PETG for chemical resistance.

>>2503984
>over the entire edge in one pass
you are using hand tools. feel free to check often and correct on the fly.
Some people when jointing intentionally hollow out the center section first and then progressively lengthen their stroke with each pass.

I also would not check with a straight edge, but the other board i'd like to joint it with.
place them on top of each other, bottom one locked in the vice. then wiggle the top one around the center axis. if it rotates effortless, you still have a center bump. if it doesnt rotate, you have 2 points of contact with a center hollow. This is what we are looking for, as the center hollow pulls tight with clamps and leaves practical invisible joint

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2502942
this isn't going to be helpful to you op but i just feel like sharing anyway, i had a similar issue where three or four times the rcd tripped when someone turned a light on or off, problem was i wasn't around when it happened and the stories changed, maybe it was this switch, maybe it was a different light, can't quite remember.
well i wasn't keen to rip out half of the house to find a frayed wire so some narrowing down was required.
so anyway about 100 quid later i'm folded up under the stairs pulling out the rcd and swapping the mcbs for rcbos, simple enough to narrow it down for sure that way.
turns out it was the oven, oven elements are apparently notorious for absorbing moisture and cracking and shorting themselves very slowly to ground.
it tripped a couple of times and i explained what the issue was and someone managed to put together that turning the top half of the oven on or off didn't trip, but as it heated up or cooled down it would trip as the element expanded, but if it tripped and you reset it would keep going fine.
so anyway swapped the element over and it was all hunky dory.
the thing about rcds is that its cumulative, your lighting circuit might have a few ma leakage by whatever means when you do x,y,z and then you have something unrelated leaking a large amount all the time, and you think oh because i turned this off it stopped, that is the culprit.
well it isn't always. just be careful.
good luck!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503069
go outside, open the outdoor lights, see if they are full of water. earth fault means current is escaping from the line-neutral loop to earth. current at the line and neutral should be the same that is kirchoffs law, if its not then its leaking somewhere (potentially through a person which is bad, or in your case through something else which isn't quite as bad but very annoying.)
if you had a bad earth connector it wouldn't trip (nowhere for the current to escape) until you touch it and you get a little shock and hopefully the rcd cuts the power before your heart stops

>Does anyone know the "archaic knowledge that was lost to time" required to make one?

Here is how you can make LED bulbs which last forever:
https://www.fingers-welt.de/phpBB/viewtopic.php?f=14&t=19109&p=418276#p418276

The trick is basically to lower the power output considerably so that the LEDs do not overheat. This way, you can make them last forever.

If you really want to use incandescent bulbs:
- buy 230V bulbs and run them on 110V
- Put a diode in one cable of the two connected to the bulb.
This will lower their output and increase the lifespan.

This is good advice; also it's a common mistake to assume that a leak is directly above where it becomes visible but water often travels along framing, pipes, wiring and other materials before dropping down and coming into view, or it might pool up until it reaches the level of a gap that lets it escape and fall.
That's both potentially good and bad as far as finding and solving the problem, the point is though that a leak that appears at the bottom of the roof or under it in/on a wall or window or floor may be from a hole at the tippy top of the roof peak and running down, and not necessarily straight down.
Back tracing it to its source is the first step, and can take time if it's not obvious or theres not enough rain to trigger it.

threads.com: how do you switch on additional solar panels during cloudy weather so that your 5kw inverter can constantly output 5kw regardless of weather?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503962
you ought to read up on solar power basics.

You don't "switch on" additional panels. If you have 100kw of panels, then that's the power they are able to produce during ideal full direct sun conditions. But they only supply the amount of power that you are actually using at any given time. If you're not presenting a load to the array, then no power will flow.
In this way it is similar to the AC electrical system in a normal house. (the power doesn't just come oozing out of a receptacle when nothing is plugged in)

last_replies.com:
>>2503991
>the issue is that my inverter will have a maximum output power of 5kW, meaning I can't connect 10kW of solar panels to it as far as in know
That's not how electricity works. Your inverter will use the amount of power it needs to use even if the panels are able to provide more.

Think of an electrical device as a vaccuum rather than thinking of the electrical supply as a pump. The panels aren't forcing electricity into the inverter, the inverter is pulling electricity from the panels. And it will only pull as much as it's going to use.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503950
This is the best point made. I guess I didn't realize the difference. Thanks anon

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503918
A bath fan isn't going to have any noticeable effect on the air in your garage, they just move such a small amount of air. Most bath exhaust fans move like 50-100 CFM, even the heavier duty ones might only do 150CFM. I would recommend instead an in-line duct fan like in this pic that can move more like 600-900 CFM.

Install a couple of 12x12 HVAC returns in the ceiling at opposite ends of the garage and connect them with some 10-12 inch flex duct. Then put a 10-12 inch inline fan somewhere in the duct between them, probably close to the middle of the duct run to minimize noise. If the fan has enough CFM it should do a decent job at circulating the air. As an added bonus you could put an air filter in the return on the intake side if you wanted.

Make sure to use insulated flex duct, if it's not insulated it will just leech heat from your attic and turn the garage into an oven in the summer.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

>I don't think they are designed to be used for long periods of time though
Should be fine. I have a shitty $30 Broan bath fan in my garden shed to help alleviate moisture and it's been running constantly for 6 or 7 years straight. The motors last a long time because they are in the air flow path and are kept very cool.

But regardless, they don't move the amount of CFM needed to have any kind of effect on a garage unless the garage is super tiny.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503248
That's called level winding (or is a type of level winding*) and is done with a winder (aka a "spooler") with a guide that moves across the open face of the spool or bobbin as it rotates...it's a fairly common feature in some styles of fishing reels and cable winches and you can get them for yarn making and winding bobbins for things like weaving-
https://hansencrafts.com/cherry-woolee-winder/
https://myautowinder.com/
Simple ones loke in fishing reels use a direct gear drive to move the guide as the main axle spins, really sophisticated ones for manufacturing have sensors that adjust the guide motion and other factors as the material diameter increases, which is how the ones like your pic are so perfect-

"In spooling or level-wind applications, material is wound onto a spool. As the material's diameter changes on the supply spool, and on the the take-up spool, it’s critical to maintain the proper speed of each spool. Encoders provide the motion feedback to help maintain that speed.

Encoder feedback also helps monitor the length of material and helps maintain the proper tension on the material to avoid stretching, breaking or winding too tightly or loosely. "

https://www.encoder.com/spooling-level-wind

*specifically it's "cross wound" and here's a whole thing on why that might be done-

https://archaicarcane.com/standing-at-a-crossroads-thread-cross-wound-vs-stack-wound/comment-page-1/

You guys use CNC mills and shit right?
I have a problem which maybe some gcode magic can solve?

So basically, it's pretty simple, i need to drill 50 holes.
I put the stock in the mill, drill the first 25 holes and then i need to flip the stock over to drill rest of the holes. But somehow i need to tell the mill that i flipped the stock over and that it is in different position now, since obviously it's not going to be centered anymore, plus it's upside down.

Before flipping and moving the stock i drilled 2 alignment holes, and then after flipping and moving the stock i went in with a probe and found the new coordinates of these 2 alignment holes, and now somehow i need to use this information to tell the mill, to adjust the position of all coordinates in the gcode file according to this.

Is this even possible?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503422
You need to use a new work coordinate.
Teach your first work coordinate as G54 in your machine. Teach your flipped coordinate as G55.
Call G54 for the first 25 holes and G55 for the 25 holes after flipping.

So do this:
G54
G-Code for your holes.

G-Code to park your spindle somewhere that allows you to access the part with your hands.
M00 (Temporary Program Stop)

G55
G-Code for the rest of your job.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: I want to get my theoreticals in order and get some general knowledge. What would you recommend? I know practice is best and I am beginning a course next week, but reading hurt no one.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503385
The best online resource in the US for what you want are the Weldingweb forums which have many professionals and are noob-friendly. There are threads on how to prepare for school and what to bring. If you've already bought a few tools you may find others useful.

Make sure you can see at welding ranges. If you haven't a recent eye exam get one and remember optometrists can write multiple prescriptions at one visit. I wear separate glasses for near vision and driving. Know what "cheaters" (plain magnifying lenses) are. Know the location of your local welding suppliers and visit them.

Different people prefer different tints and shade levels. I mostly weld with shade 9 gold or blue tinted lenses.

Have spare gloves (welding gloves are consumables) so you don't interrupt booth time replacing them. Have spare clear cover lenses for whatever helmet you wear because it's typical to expend one a day. You need to see to weld. Dress for work not the block and remember whatever you wear gets a spark bath.

A large visegrip plier is quite handy (I weld T-handles, just some 1/4" scrap rod, to the adjusting knob to use it with gloves and because tightening the handle is vastly more powerful than manual squeeze.

See what the school issues for tools. Some don't issue small angle grinders because students destroy shit. Minimum personal grinder size should be a smallish bodied 6" to use thin kerf cutting wheels as wells a 4-1/2" rocks. If your school doesn't issue flap discs and you're not poor feel free to bring some. A rugged plastic bucket is the usual welder tote with an added rope handle. There's more but go here and read your arse off and that will be sufficient for the weekend.

https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/1-WeldingWeb-Disciplines

Bongs can goto migwelding.uk for the equipment differences. Later on I advise learning how all your equipment works because in the field you'll need to care for it.

I do and 100lb tanks too, there being no downside to accumulating them (mine are stored safely outdoors). I wouldn't buy 40s unless I had a specific use for them as 100s hold more than twice that and aren't bad to hand truck, but 40s are sized for manual lifting so horses for courses.

The 40 and larger don't have the OPD which restricts flow so they're better for cutting torches and large burners. Go all Hank Hill and study LP cylinders, hoses and connectors. For example the black plastic knob on BBQ hose connectors is designed to melt away in a fire after which the fitting disconnects shutting off flow. BBQ cylinder valves are also tapped for CGA-510 AKA POL fittings which match acetylene and LP gas regulators. (I use those on heaters and cookers since I've a pile of Victors 450s).

threads.sub: Replacing my 12v car battery with 18650s without a BMS
threads.com:
We all know charging 18650s above 4.2v is bad.

Lets say my car alternator charges the lead acid battery to 14v.

If I parallel 4 x 18650 at 4.2v the maximum safe voltage would be 16.8v. This is above the max voltage the alternator outputs, which is 14v.

So at 14v each 18650 cell would be at only 3.5v, and I don't have to worry about overcharging since once the 18650s are at 14v they simply won't accept any more current since the voltage isn't rising.

Now if I add multiple parallel banks of 4 x 18650s I would have each cell at 3.5v but lot of available current, enough to start a car.

So doing it this way, I figure I don't need a BMS since there is no way the 18650s can be overcharged. Tell me if I am wrong?

each 18650 has a max discharge current of about 20a so you would have to parallel 5 to 10 cells to get 100 to 200a, then series those in 3 packs for the 12.6v.

18650's are a terrible idea for a car battery.

>>2503146
>You are utterly full of shit, parroting the nonsensical "tonewood" bullshit.
Agreed and the entire heavy/dense = better thing and the "sympathetic resonance kills sustain" argument is pulled from the deepest recesses of his ass too.
Fact is that woods used in instruments are often chosen for structural and wear and stability and working qualities far more than for subtle nuance of tone, and where they are used to affect tonal and other qualities like sustain, crisp attack, etc. they are often used in combinations of "better" more exotic species and "lesser" quality woods to fine tune resonance and other qualities in certain frequency ranges.
Cedar is very soft and not dense and is used all the time in acoustics for guitars used in music that favors its sonic qualities, like classical guitar.
Some highly prized woods like mahogany sound like shit if you build an entire guitar out of them, and need a super stiff dense wood like a maple or ebony fingerboard or body cap to give it any attack and brightness at all.
Conversely an all hard maple guitar will be all bite and attack and treble with minimal depth and warmth.

tl;dr: sustain isn't everything and there is such a thing as too much of any "good" sonic quality in a guitar; balance is what matters...but only if the thing is structurally sound and stable, which matters most.

I've built an electric kit, generic inexpensive tele style. The only woodworking I had to do with it was shape the headstock blank. Did alright but I got some splintering, probably because I went yolo with a tenon saw - I'm not much of a carpenter - but enough sanding solved the worst of the damage. For me most of the work went into the paintjob, in that I wanted to get a really good solid finish, which I achieved to my satisfaction, over months of spraying, drying, sanding, spraying, drying, sanding, etc.

The rest of the build was just bolt the parts together, so nothing complicated. Finished the neck with Danish oil, had to get a set of files to adjust the nut, try and get the whole thing set up nice. It's not a great player, or else I'd look to invest in better electronics than the cheapo stuff that came with the kit, but it's fine. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503043
Training dogs isn't that hard if you know some basic principles and avoid counterproductive methods. People who do classes tend to expect them to magically work without any extra effort; the key to any dog training being effective and sticking is to spend the right amount of time working with them, and at the right time in their development.
How much time they need to get commands or remember them, or how long a session they will tolerate before losing interest or becoming defiant just for fun depends a lot on the breed, which is another reason one size fits all classes may have limited value on their own.
But assuming you don't start too early with advanced stuff or wait until bad habits have to be unlearned, just spending the time and running through and building on basic obedience skills in a calm manner will get the typical dog used to doing what's expected of him, assuming you are *very* consistent with signals and instructions.
I mention signals first because contrary to what most people assume, using hand signals can be more effective than voice commands since dogs communicate visually. You can teach both at the same time but often when they get squirrely its the hand signal that will cut through whatever distracting them and get their attention.
They're like toddlers, and will try to interpret your voice for an angle to work and either ignore you as unserious if you try to be nice, or pout and refuse in a battle of wills if they think you aren't being nice enough.
Visual signals avoids all that and especially when more than one person will be giving commands.
But like little kids they will play any inconsistency for all they can, so you have to insist on it among the people involved, which is often more difficult than training the animal.

There are bearings in the top, and the bottom of that headset.
The spinny turny part needs held tight at the bottom, while you turn the big ring at the top that has flats like a bolt.

You unscrew it all the way and the fork comes completely out.

Clean the bearings and races out with a solvent, and then replace with real grease. any cheap NGLI2 grease from walmart.
Put it back together and itllbe good as new.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500546
^this. Shit also killed off real OTA DJs.

last_replies.name: Former Pirate Radio DJ
last_replies.com:
First off, find a frequency to operate on. If you're in a large metropolitan area, available frequencies in the FM band are going to be tough to find. Best way to do that is to drive around and tune throughout the band. Ideally, you'll want something with an open channel on both sides, but good luck.
The tricky part is determining how much power and antenna height you'll need. The simple way to figue is, if you can get an antenna about 20 - 30ft in the air, 10 watts can ideally give you a few mile radius. To double your distance, rither quadruple your power output or antenna eight.
Easiest antennas are simple 1/2 wave or 1/4 wave ground plane. You can find sites to tell you how to make those, but take a coat hanger, straighten out, and cut it to length. Use the formula 468/freq (in Mhz) then multiply by 12 to get inches for your length. Solder into a PL259 connector. Cut your radials same length and attach to the corners of the connector and bend at 45 degree angle.
20ft metal or Schedule 80 pipe works great for portable tower with a TV tripod. Use 50 ohm coax.
Transmitters can be found on E-bay. Avoid Chinese made units, for they're dirty and their singal splatters. Free Radio Berkeley still builds them by hand, but he's slow and it'll take months for him to finish.

Good luck, Anon. Read around the net to learn more. Be safe, be responsible.

>>2500162
>How would you clean mold spots off leather?
First and foremost you must ensure mold can no longer grow, otherwise the mold WILL come back. How was the leather stored? Mold can only grow well in non-ventilated areas with 70 % relative humidity or higher. If you keep storing it wherever it was stored, the mold will grow again.

Ensure that relative humidity is less than 60.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Anyone know how to get started as a jeweler? Jewelsmith?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2501420
First thing is to get a basic understanding of the range of processes involved and how they are categorized and overlap.
It's a very broad term like "woodworking", some stuff is universal and some us very specialized.
Despite the name, lots of jewelry has nothing to do with jewels, but nearly all of it uses some degree of metalsmithing.
Even among pro jewelers many of them leave all of the actual fabriction work on the gemstones to a specialist in lapidary work.
Setting stones requires an understanding of metallurgy but may not involve any actual metal fabrication work.
Same goes for assembling jewelry from pre- made beads and other findings...you need to at least understand simple wire work.

Learning basic metalsmithing principles is the most universal foundation that lets you branch out, beginning with wire forming, them moving into cutting and soldering wire, tube and sheet material.
Casting is a whole other niche that bypasses some of that stuff but still requires understanding metal properties and basic skills to do finishing and fitting/modifications.
A hammer and anvil or at least a similar hard item/surface to beat on and some soft metal wire scraps are enough to get started learning what will/won't work and how to make that happen.
